title: What should someone who wants to learn an instrument without a teacher know? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first thing you should know is you are guaranteed to sound terrible at first!! Even so, don’t let that discourage you! The number one thing to remember about learning an instrument is, “Practice makes perfect!” Next, what ever instrument you are choosing to learn, there are many beginner music books that will show you what to do to make a sound, tune that sound, turn that sound into a tune, and finally turn a tune into music. Many years ago I taught myself to play saxophone by simply focusing on the instructions and fingering charts in a beginners book. That was the first week of school that year and by the end of the first semester I had reached 2nd chair over 4 other students who were in weekly lessons with a teacher! As the years progressed I moved on from Alto sax to Baritone. The best compliment I have ever received while performing came after one of our Christmas concerts. The head of our school’s History department asked me who our amazing bassoonist was and I had to reply that we didn’t have one, the instrument she was hearing was my Baritone Saxophone! Now, when I think back to that first week, it was a struggle. I was squawking, squeaking and totally terrible, but with patience, persistence, a few tips from fellow players, and lots of practice I had achieved such a skill level that I could make that big, bellowing beast made of brass sound just like the much smaller, more mellow, mahogany king of orchestral bass woodwinds. Thus I come back around to my previous statement, “Practice makes Perfect!”

ORIGINAL QUESTION: What should someone who wants to learn an instrument without a teacher know? Anyone who wishes to self-teach themselves anything will do well to acknowledge beforehand that: Your student will be highly motivated.Your teacher will be terrible.Some important details will inevitably be skipped because you don’t know what you don’t know.Ultimately everyone is “self-taught”, meaning: You have to do the work. The greatest teacher in the world can’t drag you, kicking and screaming, to proficiency. The only way to “get good” is to practice and practice and practice some more.Ultimately, everyone learns from those who went before, be that teachers, more experienced players, YouTube vids, books, or whatever medium you choose. Knowledge is knowledge. Seek it out wherever it may be found.Learn the difference between practicing and playing.Remember, the reason you’re doing all that practicing is so you can have fun playing. Don’t forget to have fun playing.

I think in a situation like this ,everyone needs to be aware that even a relatively bad teacher is better than trying to learn without guidance , as its so easy to over emphasise some aspects and under emphasise others if you rely on tutor books ,and this is also true of relying on online guidance . Someone who has already learned to play an instrument reasonably well would have gone through this process and know when to move onto new goals and not to drag with older goals , they would also know how to use a variety of material in different styles to help a student develop with a wide perspective . I would really recommend finding a tutor and talking to them at length before accepting them as a tutor , ( or they you as a student) maybe have a trial run of lessons before you fully commit . It would yield positive results .

It’s absolutely possible to gain a level of proficiency on an instrument, but it takes more time and motivation to push through when it’s difficult. That can be really hard to do when inspiration is lacking, so listen to lots of different artists who play your chosen instrument, as well as a wide range of other music. I taught myself guitar for 2 years before taking lessons - I already played keyboards, so I had a headstart. I enjoyed it and made fairly decent progress, but once I started taking lessons, my playing progressed exponentially and I was introduced to styles I wouldn’t have explored otherwise. I’ve also got a more solid understanding of how music works, so I can improvise and have also been able to pick up other instruments since. If you take up lessons, you get more out of the lessons the more you put in - from a teacher’s perspective, my students who are dedicated to practicing not only progress quicker but have developed a love of music. Lessons are an investment, but one that will enrich your life. Hope this helps, Rob
You should figure out why it’s important to you to learn without a teacher. I’ve had a 60 year career based on music I stole from other players.
What you should know is that is important to have a teacher. Without a teacher, you don’t know what you don’t know.

I think you can start without a teacher. However, at some point you will likely plateau and become discouraged. That happened to me with the guitar. Additionally, without guidance, you will likely accept and play to your weakness and not learn how to overcome them. That means you will accumulate a many bad habits.
